courses.title: Introduction to Data Analytics
courses.description: Introduces students to foundational concepts that are used in the data analytics industry to understand and frame projects

courses.title: Descriptive Analytics
courses.description: Introduces students to the core areas of descriptive analytics, where the main objective is to answer "what happened" in a project. Students will learn how to accurately describe the attributes of data variables available to them for their projects. Students will have the opportunity to work on real-life projects and cases throughout the course, learning the importance of communicating findings to different constituents.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite (PSYCH 200orSTAT 200orSTAT 250orSCM 200) and (DA 101orDS 200)

courses.title: Diagnostic Analytics
courses.description: This course takes descriptive data a step further by examining the relationships between variables through root cause analysis. Students will learn current tools and techniques that allow analysts to explain why the patterns are observed in data and discover relationships between two or more attributes of the data.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite DA 201WorDA 101

courses.title: Predictive Analytics
courses.description: Helps students learn to predict what will happen in future events based on historical data. Students will learn how to properly examine problem contexts to use the most appropriate method to develop the best predictive model as well as how to evaluate their results and interpret findings to users at different levels of an organization.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite DA 301

courses.title: Data Ethics and Privacy
courses.description: Cultivates awareness of ethical, privacy, and security rules and standards to guide how to use and analyze data and communicate the findings. The course will emphasize ethics at various stages of data analytics, including the communication of the implications of data analysis to stakeholders, how data is collected and stored, as well as how it is analyzed and presented to different stakeholders.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite DA 101

courses.title: Prescriptive Analytics
courses.description: Introduces students to how data analytics assists in making decisions and advocating for a course of action. Helps students learn to develop a set of viable decision options, rank those decision options to create alternative courses of action, and achieve an optimal decision.

courses.title: Qualitative Analytics
courses.description: Offers an overview of data analytics techniques for non-numeric data (e.g., text, videos, or images). Students will explore methodological reasons for a qualitative rather than a quantitative approach, and the underlying challenges with this type of data, depending on the hypothesis or research question. A strong background in statistics is required for this course.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite DA 201W Concurrent ENGL 202AorENGL 202BorENGL 202CorENGL 202D

courses.title: Data Analytics Implementation Capstone I
courses.description: This course allows students to demonstrate their ability to use industry or organization data to develop a descriptive, diagnostic, predictive, and prescriptive analysis. This portion of the capstone addresses the understanding of the industry data, project scope, data journalism, and descriptive analysis.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite DA 302WandDA 305andMIS 447 Concurrent MGMT 409

courses.title: Data Analytics Implementation Capstone II
courses.description: This course continues the industry project (assigned in DA 475) and the remaining three-part analysis of organization-specific analysis (diagnostic, predictive, and prescriptive).

courses.title: Data Visualization
courses.description: Presents techniques and software used for data visualization. Students will be introduced to complex data sets and learn how to present findings in interactive and innovative ways.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite PSYCH 200orSTAT 200

courses.title: Simulations of Human Behavior
courses.description: Students will develop an understanding of the systems, processes, tools, and implications of this field.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite 3 credits of programming and 3 credits of mathematics

courses.title: Effective Writing: Technical Writing
courses.description: Writing for students in scientific and technical disciplines.

courses.title: Language, Logic, and Discrete Mathematics
courses.description: Introduction to formal languages, mathematical logic, and discrete mathematics, with applications to information sciences and technology.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MATH 110orMATH 140

courses.title: Project Management for Non-Business Majors
courses.description: Covers the technical and people skills related to project management within a variety of organizational structures. Students learn the tools and concepts needed to successfully balance schedule, budget, and scope while managing risk and resources during the project life cycle. Leadership and teamwork skills are emphasized and practiced in a hands-on approach.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite 5th-semester standing

courses.title: Social Media Management and Analytics
courses.description: In-depth analysis of social media management, digital marketing, SEO/M, and analytics of current digital business practices. Presents an analysis of current issues in digital marketing and the tools needed to assess those issues.

courses.title: Data Warehousing
courses.description: Using case studies in various business domains, exercises, and projects, this course presents practical dimensional modeling techniques, extract/transformation/load (ETL) logic, ETL design considerations, and report generation. Key concepts related to data warehousing, including dimensional table characteristics, fact table characteristics and granularity, types of dimensions, types of fact tables, dimension attribute hierarchies, consolidated fact tables, slowly changing dimension techniques, and multivalued dimensions and weighting factors are covered in the course.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MIS 336or equivalent approved course

courses.title: Ethics
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the basic questions of ethics, the major currents in traditional ethical theory (virtue ethics, deontology, consequentialism), and more recent developments (e.g., care ethics).

courses.title: Introduction to R
courses.description: This course will introduce students to data computing fundamentals and a reproducible workflow using the R programming language and related tools. R is a powerful, open-source programming language used widely for applications in statistics and data science. Students will be expected to access, join, wrangle, clean, and visualize real data from various sources (e.g., CSV, HTML scraping, web URL, R packages).
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 21or higher

courses.title: Introduction to Programming Techniques
courses.description: Introduction to programming techniques design and implementation of algorithms. Structured programming. Problem-solving techniques. Introduction to a high-level language, including arrays, procedures, and recursion
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MATH 110or prerequisite or concurrentMATH 140

courses.title: Rhetoric and Composition
courses.description: Prepares students both to understand the communications that surrounds them and to succeed in their own communication efforts. The course focuses specifically on analyzing verbal and visual texts (reading) as well as on producing such texts (writing), always in terms of rhetorical principles.

courses.title: Techniques of Calculus I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change, and the underlying mathematical behaviors that model real-life economics and financial applications. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques, and how to use a calculus framework to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MATH 022or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Calculus With Analytic Geometry I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change and creating mathematical models that replicate real-life phenomena. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques and how to use the calculus environment to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MATH 22andMATH 26orMATH 26and satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination.

courses.title: Database Management Systems
courses.description: Theory and utilization of database management systems in organizations, including data modeling and applications development.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MIS 204orMIS 110orCMPSC 121orCMPSC 102

courses.title: Organization of Data
courses.description: Introduction to the concept of databases, including the storage, manipulation, evaluation, and display of data, and related issues.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics in Psychology
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the descriptive and inferential statistics commonly used in psychology, and to hypothesis testing as a method of scientific investigation. It also explores the ways in which the assumptions of statistical tests place constraints on experimental design and, conversely, how the design of experiments can dictate the statistical test appropriate for data analysis.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite PSYCH 100andMATH 21

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 21or higher.

courses.title: Analytics in Business
courses.description: Introduction to the use of analytics in business contexts, including data-driven decision-making and performance optimization in areas such as finance, management information systems, marketing, international business, accounting, and economics.

courses.title: Analytics in Engineering
courses.description: Introduction to the application of analytics in engineering, with a focus on system optimization, process improvement, and predictive modeling in engineering problems.

courses.title: Analytics in Science
courses.description: Introduction to the use of analytics in natural sciences, covering topics like experimental data analysis, statistical modeling, and simulation in scientific research.

courses.title: Analytics in Humanities and the Social Sciences
courses.description: Introduction to the application of analytics in humanities and social sciences, including text analysis, thematic and content analysis, statistical modeling, regression analysis, media analytics, program evaluation, trend analysis, text mining, demography, ethnography, simulation, and the interpretation of cultural data in fields such as education, psychology, sociology, political science, communication, cultural studies, history, and language arts.

courses.title: Corporation Finance
courses.description: Nature of finance function; risk and return concepts; working capital; dividend policies; mergers; security markets; acquisition and management of corporate capital; analysis of operations; forecasting capital requirements; raising capital; and planning profits. Available to baccalaureate students only.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite (ENGL 15orENGL 30)andACCTG 211and (ECON 102orECON 104) and (SCM 200orSTAT 200)

courses.title: Intermediate Financial Modeling
courses.description: The course focuses primarily on the development of spreadsheet applications and the use of the case method to apply decision-making procedures to real-world problems in finance areas.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite FIN 301

courses.title: Investment and Portfolio Analysis
courses.description: Investment and risk, types of security investments, sources of investment information, the broker, the stock market, portfolio management.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite FIN 301 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Use Cases in Financial Analytics
courses.description: 6–10 case studies demonstrating types of studies in financial analytics

courses.title: Introductory Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to general psychology; principles of human behavior and their applications.

courses.title: Basic Research Methods in Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to methods of psychological research, with special attention to hypothesis formation and testing, threats to validity, and data presentation.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite PSYCH 100andPSYCH 200orSTAT 200

courses.title: Principles of Measurement
courses.description: An introductory course about properties of test scores such as reliability and validity. In addition, the course focuses on the construction and evaluation of measurement instruments used in educational and psychological settings and may include topics such as test development, score reporting, and interpretation. Basic statistics are introduced throughout the course to interpret the psychometric properties of scores.

courses.title: Program Evaluation
courses.description: Identify and understand the normative assumptions specific to organizations about their basic program design, implementation, and assessment processes.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite (PSYCH 100orSOC 1) and (PSYCH 200orSTAT 200) andPSYCH 301W

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.
courses.prerequisites_text: GS This course can be used to satisfy the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Introduction to Health Services Organization
courses.description: Examination of the social, political, historic, and scientific factors in the development and organization of health services.

courses.title: An Introduction to Data in the Health Care System
courses.description: This course examines the broad topic of data and health care decisions, particularly how to be an astute consumer of data about health, the health care system, and health policy.

courses.title: Health Care Payment
courses.description: This course covers basic concepts and issues related to health insurance and payment for health care providers.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite ECON 102orHPA 101

courses.title: Financial Decisions in Health Care Organizations
courses.description: An introduction to financial and economic information to make decisions in health care organizations.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite HPA 210

courses.title: Health Services Policy Issues
courses.description: Analysis of major issues in health services delivery in hospitals, medical practice, public health, mental health, and health professional education.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite ECON 102orHPA 101orPLSC 001

courses.title: Health Care and Medical Needs
courses.description: Health care from an individual, family, and community standpoint illustrated with specific diseases and health problems.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite BBH 101orBISC 004orBIOL 141orBIOL 161 Concurrent HPA 101

courses.title: Population Health and Health Care
courses.description: This course covers fundamental theories, concepts, issues, and strategies related to a population health approach to health and health services.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite HPA 101

courses.title: Health Systems Management
courses.description: Introduction to and analysis of managerial roles and practices in health service organizations.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite (HPA 211orACCTG 212) andHPA 101

courses.title: Professional Development in Health Policy and Administration
courses.description: Development of personal understanding and professional skills to prepare students for future employment or study in health policy and administration.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite HPA 101

courses.title: Field Experience in Health Policy and Administration
courses.description: Professional field experience providing opportunities to apply skills and knowledge in health care setting.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite HPA 301,HPA 310,HPA 332,HPA 390W Full-Time Equivalent Course Full-time equivalent (FTE) classes have been approved to be offered as full time regardless of the number of credits the class is worth.

courses.title: Strategic Planning and Marketing for Health Services
courses.description: Introduction to principles and methods of strategic planning and marketing.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite HPA 395

courses.title: American Politics: Principles, Processes and Powers
courses.description: This course examines the American democracy by looking at the dynamic interaction between the founding ideals of the United States government, the institutions established by the Constitution, and the ongoing contest for power within and through those institutions.
courses.prerequisites_text: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming
courses.description: Fundamentals of computational thinking, including reasoning about problems at multiple levels of abstraction, and analyzing code for its behavior, efficiency, and correctness.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MATH 21or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Introduction to Spreadsheets and Databases
courses.description: Design, use, and programming of spreadsheets and data bases with applications from a range of disciplines.
courses.prerequisites_text: Note not currently offered online through World Campus. Prerequisite 2 entrance units in mathematics

courses.title: Introduction to Management Information Systems
courses.description: Provides an overview of the role of information systems in business process design; the current technologies used for obtaining, storing, securing, and communicating information in support of operations and decision-making within a business organization; as well as the concepts and principles for developing and using popular spreadsheet and database tools.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 021or higher. GQ This course can be used to satisfy the Quantification (GQ) requirement.

courses.title: Health Care Leadership
courses.description: This course provides an opportunity to students to learn about the challenges of leadership in health care.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite HPA 301orHPA 311orHPA 332

courses.title: Culturally Competent Health Services for Diverse Populations
courses.description: This course examines the broad concept of diversity and its impact on health care, particularly on rendering services to patients from diverse groups and about the challenges health care professionals face serving diverse populations. Diversity includes many factors, such as age, ethnicity, race, religion, physical and mental disability, class, gender, and sexual orientation. To eradicate health disparities and improve health outcomes, students will explore effective and culturally appropriate strategies and interventions to deliver health care to diverse health care consumers.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite HPA 311

courses.title: Principles of Epidemiology
courses.description: Theory of epidemiology and significant case studies. Potential application to health care.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite (BBH 310orBIOL 230WorHPA 311) and (STAT 200orSTAT 250) Note This course is typically offered asBBH 440

courses.title: Long-Term Care Management
courses.description: Management and policy issues for institutional, community, and home settings for chronic care services.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite HPA 332

courses.title: Human Resource Management in Health Care Organizations
courses.description: Foundations of human resource management applied to health care organizations, including hospitals, long-term care facilities, and community health organizations.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite HPA 332

courses.title: Health Care Quality
courses.description: This course covers the basic principles and techniques of quality management in health care, including the definition, measurement, and uses of data for improving the quality of health and health services.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite HPA 332

courses.title: Undergraduate Seminar
courses.description: Involves a thematic or topical investigation with an emphasis on historical criticism and analysis; students will pursue the study of one historical topic in detail in this writing intensive course.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite 4th semester standing

courses.title: American Civilization to 1877
courses.description: An historical survey of the American experience from its colonial beginnings through the Civil War and Reconstruction.

courses.title: American Civilization Since 1877
courses.description: An historical survey of the American experience from the emergence of urban-industrial society in the late nineteenth century to the present.

courses.title: Medieval Europe
courses.description: Covers the development of political, judicial, and diplomatic institutions; the role of religion as a significant element of medieval society; the development of royal houses; and changes in economic and social life of medieval Europe.

courses.title: History of Modern Europe since 1789
courses.description: Political, social, and ideological developments; origin and impact of two World Wars; totalitarianism and democracy; changing role in the world.

courses.title: The World at War: 1914-1918
courses.description: Explores the military and political elements of World War I along with its profound impact on societies; topics include battle dynamics, state policies, and life on the home front — labor unrest, food insecurity, welfare efforts, and refugees.

courses.title: The World at War: 1939-1945
courses.description: In-depth study of the origins and conduct of World War II. Political and economic aspects as well as military.

courses.title: Introduction to U.S. Environmental History
courses.description: Explores changing relationships between humans and the natural world, while examining American landscape, environmental activism, and the development of ideas about nature. Major themes include the natural context of American history and the socially constructed and historically contingent knowledge about nature.

courses.title: Introduction to U.S. Food History
courses.description: Analyzes the history of agriculture and food production in the U.S., examining consumption patterns, the food industry, marketing, and regulation. Also explores the impact of food systems on human well-being and addresses issues of sustainability, productivity, social effects, and environmental impacts.

courses.title: Women in United States History
courses.description: Focuses on key historical developments in women’s history, including actual experiences as members of a class, a race, and an ethnic community; the progress women have made as individuals, workers, and citizens; as well as the opposition they have faced.

courses.title: Introduction to the Civil War Era, 1848 through 1877
courses.description: Survey of the causes and consequences of America's deadliest conflict, the Civil War, from the end of the U.S.-Mexican War in 1848 through the end of Reconstruction in 1877.

courses.title: History of Science I
courses.description: Surveys the history of science and scientific inquiry on a global scale from the Neolithic period to the 19th century.

courses.title: Islamic States, Societies and Cultures c. 600-1500
courses.description: Introduces students to the history and culture of the Islamic world; develops a historical framework for understanding developments in religious and legal thought and practice, science, medicine, and technology, philosophy, and the arts.

courses.title: Latin-American History Since 1820
courses.description: Examines the history of modern Latin America, including the geographic and political development of the region, the development of various economic models, and the widespread extraction of labor focusing on African slavery and Indigenous exploitation.

courses.title: Introduction to the Middle East
courses.description: Origins of Islamic civilization; expansion of Islam; the Ottoman Empire; the Middle East since 1918.

courses.title: Society and Culture in the Pacific War
courses.description: Looks at the origins, nature, and consequences of World War II in the Pacific; assesses different nations, political movements, ideologies, and empires that clashed across Asia-Pacific from 1931 to 1945.

courses.title: Modern Iran
courses.description: Surveys modern Iranian history from the 19th century to the present day, analyzing significant events, policies, and revolutions in local, regional, and global contexts. Students learn key concepts, make comparisons, and understand the broader historical trends of the 20th century.

courses.title: Modern Iran
courses.description: Surveys modern Iranian history from the 19th century to the present day, analyzing significant events, policies, and revolutions in local, regional, and global contexts. Students learn key concepts, make comparisons, and understand the broader historical trends of the 20th century.

courses.title: History of Science I
courses.description: Surveys the history of science and scientific inquiry on a global scale from the Neolithic period to the 19th century.

courses.title: The Roman Republic and Empire
courses.description: History of the Roman Republic and Empire from the origins of Rome to the disintegration of the Empire.

courses.title: Medieval Europe
courses.description: Covers the development of political, judicial, and diplomatic institutions; the role of religion as a significant element of medieval society; the development of royal houses; and changes in economic and social life of medieval Europe.

courses.title: Islamic States, Societies and Cultures c. 600-1500
courses.description: Introduces students to the history and culture of the Islamic world; develops a historical framework for understanding developments in religious and legal thought and practice, science, medicine, and technology, philosophy, and the arts.

courses.title: The History of Madness, Mental Illness, and Psychiatry
courses.description: Examines the ideas that have shaped European and American perceptions of madness, insanity, and mental illness; the changing experiences of those afflicted; the development of those professions designed to look after those deemed mad, insane, and mentally ill; and the social and cultural assumptions behind treatments, policies, and public opinions.

courses.title: The Holocaust
courses.description: In-depth study of the history of the Holocaust in Europe that puts special emphasis on primary sources.

courses.title: Revolutionary America, 1753–1783
courses.description: Explores the forces in Great Britain and America that caused withdrawal of thirteen colonies from the British Empire and the Revolutionary War.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite HIST 020, 3 additional credits in history

courses.title: Recent American History
courses.description: Contemporary economic, social, and political aspects of the United States and its role as a world power since 1945.

courses.title: Constitutional History since 1877
courses.description: Provides an understanding of the Constitutional developments from laissez-faire to the welfare state; imperialism, war, internationalism; the contemporary court, civil liberties, and civil rights.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite Prerequisites:HIST 020orHIST 021, plus 3 additional credits in history or political science.

courses.title: American Environmental History
courses.description: The history of the ways Americans have used and thought about the environment since 1500.

courses.title: History of Work in America
courses.description: A study of selected problems in the history of work in the United States, especially since 1877.

courses.title: The Contemporary Middle East
courses.description: Focuses on the political, economic, and social changes in Turkey, Iran, Israel, and the Arab countries in the twentieth century; explores the Arab-Israeli conflict.
courses.prerequisites_text: Note This course will fulfill the Global History requirement at the 400 level.

courses.title: History of Imperialism and Nationalism in Africa
courses.description: Theories and types of imperialism; varied patterns of colonial administration; initial African responses; nationalism; decolonization and independence.
courses.prerequisites_text: Note This course will fulfill the Global History requirement at the 400 level.

courses.title: China in Revolution
courses.description: Explores the complex social and cultural history of modern China from 1900 to the present, including the formation of the modern nation-state, the development of communism, and the relationship between elite and popular culture.
courses.prerequisites_text: Note This course will fulfill the Global History requirement at the 400 level.

rules.name: Prescribed Courses for the Major (18 credits)

courses.title: Introduction to Human Development and Family Studies
courses.description: Introduction to psychosocial and family development at all stages of the individual and family life cycle.

courses.title: Values and Ethics in Health and Human Development Professions
courses.description: Examines bases for choices among values in personal and professional relations in human development processes and supporting services.

courses.title: Human Development and Family Studies Interventions
courses.description: Survey of individual and family formal and informal intervention efforts; historical and current perspectives and approaches.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite HDFS 129

courses.title: Empirical Inquiry in Human Development
courses.description: Introduction to the skills involved in critical thinking in general and the methods of empirical inquiry in particular.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite a grade of C or better required inEDPSY 101orSTAT 200

courses.title: Family Development
courses.description: Family functions over the life course; family from a multidisciplinary perspective, emphasizing adaptation and change.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite HDFS 129 or3 credits in social, behavioral, or human biological sciences

courses.title: Family Relationships
courses.description: Dynamics of family interaction; effects of parenthood, sibling and intergeneration relationships on family solidarity.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite HDFS 312W and(HDFS 315YorHDFS 315W)

rules.name: Additional Courses for the Major (13 credits)

courses.title: Infant and Child Development
courses.description: Theory, research, and methods of social/behavioral/biological sciences related to developmental processes and intervention during infancy and childhood.

courses.title: Adolescent Development
courses.description: Social, behavioral, and biological development and intervention throughout adolescence.

courses.title: Adult Development and Aging
courses.description: Physiological, psychological, and social development and intervention from young adulthood through old age.

rules.name: United States Cultures and STAT 200 (7 credits)

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite 2 units of algebra

courses.description: Theory and research related to interpersonal conditions which facilitate personal growth; intensive interpersonal competency training.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite (HDFS 311 andHDFS 312W)or 6 credits in human development and family studies or psychology

courses.title: Resolving Human Development and Family Problems
courses.description: Strategies for, and roles of professional specialists in, the solution of problems in human development and family functioning.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite HDFS 312W and6 credits in human development and family studies or psychology

courses.title: Development and Administration of Human Services Programs
courses.description: Fundamentals of program development and administration of human service programs in community settings; emphasis given to program content, strategies, and the overall planning process.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite HDFS 311

courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite (HDFS 229orPSYCH 212) andHDFS 312W

courses.description: Processes of development and change of behavior from early adulthood through old age, emphasizing theory, method, and empirical research.

courses.description: Planning and preparation for field experience in human service setting. Analysis of human service system and arrangement of site.

courses.description: Introduction to formal languages, mathematical logic, and discrete mathematics, with applications to information sciences and technology.

courses.description: Problem-based approach to technology integration by focusing on real-life problems faced by an organization.

courses.description: Second of two design and development studio courses for IST and SRA students.

courses.description: Introduction to distributed-object computing and its use in client/server and real-world computing applications.

courses.description: Introduction to the engineering of complex software systems, including software system specification, design and implementation, integration and test, and evolution.

courses.description: Students will learn how to assemble a portfolio that reflects their progress, knowledge, and insight into college-level study.

courses.title: Independent Studies
courses.description: Creative projects, including research and design, which are supervised on an individual basis and which fall outside the scope of formal courses.

courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the basic questions of ethics, the major currents in traditional ethical theory (virtue ethics, deontology, consequentialism), and more recent developments (e.g., care ethics).

courses.title: Ethics
courses.description: Focuses on ethics from both a normative and behavioral perspective; four interrelated and mutually reinforcing subject areas will be explored in the course at the individual, organizational and transnational levels business ethics, ethics in unionized firms, corporate social responsibility, and sustainability
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite LHR 100or 5th semester standing or 3 other credits of LHR

courses.title: Ethical Leadership
courses.description: Leaders, in whatever context, make difficult decisions, distribute scarce resources, direct and influence the conduct of others, and represent the goals of the enterprise they lead. Thus they ought to exemplify prudence, fairness, integrity, honesty, trustworthiness, sincerity, and morally upright behavior. This course investigates these concepts and the moral dilemmas that arise in developing or applying them.

courses.title: Qualitative Research Methods
courses.description: An understanding of both qualitative research methods and the theoretical frameworks that inform qualitative inquiry. Additionally, this course focuses on tools for data collection such as individual and focus-group interviewing and observing and recording interaction. This course provides practical experience for students in collecting and analyzing qualitative data with and without the use of technology and examines particular difficulties in the interpretation and reporting of qualitative findings. Qualitative Research Methods is course that bridges disciplinary boundaries and is useful to any student who will be investigating human interaction.

courses.title: Basic Research Methods in Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to methods of psychological research, with special attention to hypothesis formation and testing, threats to validity, and data presentation.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite PSYCH 100andPSYCH 200orSTAT 200

courses.title: Research Methods in Sociology
courses.description: Experiential-based course covering the four main social research methods: available data, survey research, experiments, and field research.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite 3 credits in Sociology

courses.title: American Politics: Principles, Processes and Powers
courses.description: This course examines the American democracy by looking at the dynamic interaction between the founding ideals of the United States government, the institutions established by the Constitution, and the ongoing contest for power within and through those institutions.

courses.title: Contemporary Political Ideologies
courses.description: Critical analysis of contemporary political ideologies such as liberalism, conservatism, socialism, anarchism, fascism, feminism, and environmentalism.

courses.title: Comparing Politics around the Globe
courses.description: This course examines the variety of ways that people seek and wield power around the world. Through cross-national comparison and individual country analysis, the course considers different forms of democratic and authoritarian regimes, sources of stability and change in different regime types, and the relationship between cultural, economic, and social factors and political processes.

courses.title: Government and Politics of Europe
courses.description: This course introduces students to the politics and governing institutions of European countries through a historical and comparative perspective.

courses.title: International Relations
courses.description: Characteristics of modern nation-states and forces governing their international relations; nationalism; imperialism; diplomacy; current problems of war and peace.

courses.title: International Political Economy
courses.description: The transnational politics of trade, investment, aid, raw materials, and the environment; nation-states, multinational corporations, and the U.N.

courses.title: International Relations Theory
courses.description: A survey of traditional and contemporary conceptual frameworks and theoretical approaches for the analysis of international relations.

courses.title: The Politics of Terrorism
courses.description: Analysis of political terrorism as a violent alternative for peaceful change and traditional warfare in the nuclear age.

courses.description: Principles of American foreign policy; processes of policy formulation; roles of the President, Congress, the State Department, and other government agencies.

courses.description: Introduction to various methods of analyzing strategic behavior using social choice and game theories.

courses.description: This course will examine the inter-relationship of foreign, military and economic policy.

courses.title: Communication Theory
courses.description: This course is intended as a foundational course in communication theory for Communication Arts and Sciences majors and others interested in social science theory in general. It is designed to show how communication theory can be applied to understand and improve communication in your professional (and personal) life. The theories examined will span the range of communication contexts, including interpersonal, group, organizational, mediated, and cross-cultural interactions.

courses.title: Qualitative Research Methods
courses.description: An understanding of both qualitative research methods and the theoretical frameworks that inform qualitative inquiry. Additionally, this course focuses on tools for data collection such as individual and focus-group interviewing and observing and recording interaction. This course provides practical experience for students in collecting and analyzing qualitative data with and without the use of technology and examines particular difficulties in the interpretation and reporting of qualitative findings. Qualitative Research Methods is course that bridges disciplinary boundaries and is useful to any student who will be investigating human interaction.

courses.title: Communication Ethics (WAC)
courses.description: Ethical issues in public and private communication; role of communication in expressing and realizing individual and social values.

courses.description: Students will learn how to assemble a portfolio that reflects their progress, knowledge, and insight into college-level study.

courses.title: Ethical Leadership
courses.description: Leaders, in whatever context, make difficult decisions, distribute scarce resources, direct and influence the conduct of others, and represent the goals of the enterprise they lead. Thus they ought to exemplify prudence, fairness, integrity, honesty, trustworthiness, sincerity, and morally upright behavior. This course investigates these concepts and the moral dilemmas that arise in developing or applying them.

courses.description: This course provides students with the tools to empirically evaluate policy proposals and outcomes in the American states.

courses.title: Strategy and Politics
courses.description: Introduction to various methods of analyzing strategic behavior using social choice and game theories.

courses.title: American Foreign Policy

courses.title: International Relations of the Middle East
courses.description: The international relations of the Middle East, stressing national security policies of regional and outside actors, and major contemporary conflicts.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite PLSC 14orHIST 181

courses.description: An examination of how politics and public policy affect and are shaped by the news media, as a political institution, in America.

courses.title: American Constitutional Law
courses.description: The origins of judicial review, landmark decisions of the Supreme Court, and their impact on the American form of government.

courses.title: The American Legal Process
courses.description: Analysis of the roles, procedures, and policies characterizing the American legal system.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite PLSC 1

courses.title: American Judicial Behavior
courses.description: Analyzes behavior of judges and other participants in the legal process; examines how and why courts function as policymaking bodies.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite PLSC 1

courses.title: Congress and the Presidency
courses.description: Basic characteristics and processes of the national legislature and executive; roles and interaction of these institutions in the policy process.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite PLSC 1

courses.title: Policy Making and Evaluation
courses.description: Advanced analysis of public policy, emphasizing policy evaluation and the factors that determine policy success and failure.

courses.title: Financial and Managerial Accounting for Decision-Making
courses.description: Introduction to the role of accounting numbers in the process of managing a business and in investor decision-making.

courses.title: Effective Speech
courses.description: Introduction to speech communication: formal speaking, group discussion, analysis and evaluation of messages.

courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.

courses.title: Introductory Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: National income measurement; aggregate economic models; money and income; policy problems.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Business Writing
courses.description: Writing reports and other common forms of business communication.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite (ENGL 15 orESL 15 orENGL 30) and 4th-semester standing OR (ENGL 137H andENGL 138T) and 4th-semester standing

courses.title: Corporation Finance
courses.description: Nature of finance function; risk and return concepts; working capital; dividend policies; mergers; security markets; acquisition and management of corporate capital; analysis of operations; forecasting capital requirements; raising capital; and planning profits. Available to baccalaureate students only.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite (ENGL 15orENGL 30)andACCTG 211and (ECON 102orECON 104) and (SCM 200orSTAT 200)

courses.title: Basic Management Concepts
courses.description: Study of fundamental principles and processes available to the understanding of management.

courses.title: Human Resource Management
courses.description: Introduction to the strategic planning and implementation of human resource management, including staffing, development, appraisal, and rewards.

courses.description: Advanced course in project management focusing on a more in-depth approach to project planning and scheduling and resource management.

courses.title: Introduction to Management Information Systems
courses.description: Provides an overview of the role of information systems in business process design; the current technologies used for obtaining, storing, securing, and communicating information in support of operations and decision-making within a business organization; as well as the concepts and principles for developing and using popular spreadsheet and database tools.

courses.title: Principles of Marketing
courses.description: Covers terminology and important concepts related to marketing in the business environment. Domestic and international environments that impact marketing are included, with particular emphasis on the marketing environment, segmentation, positioning, and targeting.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite ENGL 015orENGL 030;ECON 102orECON 104;MATH 021or higher or satisfactory score on the mathematics placement examination.

courses.title: Supply Chain Management
courses.description: Supply chain management concepts, principles, and methodologies.

courses.title: Operations Planning and Control
courses.description: Aggregate production planning procedures, disaggregation methods in hierarchical production planning, sales and operations planning, master production scheduling, material requirements planning, production activity control, lot-sizing, and capacity planning.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite SCM 301

courses.title: Purchasing and Materials Management
courses.description: Purchasing policies, procedures, order specifications and agreements, supplier selection, and the role of purchasing in production planning and inventory management.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite SCM 301orSCM 310

courses.title: Social, Legal, and Ethical Environment of Business
courses.description: Explores the ethical, political, social, legal and regulatory, technological, and demographic diversity environment of business.
courses.prerequisites_text: Note A student may not receive credit toward graduation for bothBLAW 243andBA 243.

courses.title: Strategic Business Planning
courses.description: Study of strategic planning and implementation in multi-industry, multicultural, and multi-national settings with emphasis on sustaining competitive advantages.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite BA 321andBA 322andBA 421andFIN 301andMGMT 301andMKTG 301andSCM 301 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Rhetoric and Composition
courses.description: Prepares students both to understand the communications that surrounds them and to succeed in their own communication efforts. The course focuses specifically on analyzing verbal and visual texts (reading) as well as on producing such texts (writing), always in terms of rhetorical principles.

courses.title: Techniques of Calculus I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change, and the underlying mathematical behaviors that model real-life economics and financial applications. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques, and how to use a calculus framework to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MATH 022or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Calculus With Analytic Geometry I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change and creating mathematical models that replicate real-life phenomena. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques and how to use the calculus environment to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MATH 22andMATH 26orMATH 26and satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination.

courses.title: Project Management
courses.description: Gain the ability to exert leadership in managing project teams, an understanding of people and behavioral skills, and the ability to effectively use computer-based scheduling and tracking software.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MGMT 301and (SCM 301orSCM 310)

courses.title: Project Portfolio Management and Organizations
courses.description: An advanced course in project management focusing on portfolio planning and control within the context of specific organizational challenges.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite SCM 301and (MGMT 409orMGMT 410orBA 421)

courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite SCM 301orSCM 310

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 21or higher.

courses.title: International Business and Society
courses.description: Business organizations and the sociocultural environment; current issues; corporate responsibility; international and multinational business environments.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite ENGL 202DandMGMT 301

courses.description: Financial decision-making in an international environment. Emphasis on topics relevant to small businesses and entrepreneurs.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite FIN 301

courses.title: International Business Operations
courses.description: A survey of the major aspects of international business environment and operations with an emphasis on the cultural dimension.

courses.title: International Management
courses.description: Examines issues of nations and cultures including motivation, communication, negotiation, leadership, ethics and social responsibility, and women in management.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite BA 304orMGMT 301

courses.title: Global Marketing
courses.description: Role of international marketing in the global environment; political, economic, geographic, historical, cultural conditions; developing and implementing international marketing strategies.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite BA 303orMKTG 301W

courses.description: Introduces strategic, tactical, and operational supply chain concepts including demand forecasting, risk analysis, revenue management, distribution, and facility location.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite SCM 301

courses.description: Introduction to general psychology; principles of human behavior and their applications.

courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite PSYCH 100

courses.title: Neurological Bases of Human Behavior
courses.description: An introduction to biopsychology, emphasizing the structure and function of the human brain.

courses.description: Developmental principles; physical growth; linguistic, intellectual, emotional, and social development from infancy to maturity.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite PSYCH 100

courses.description: Introduction to Social Psychology discusses how people's thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are influenced by other people (real or imagined). The course will provide an overview of the field, potentially covering such topics as: attitudes, persuasion, person perception, automatic vs. conscious thought, the self, prosocial behavior, aggression, interpersonal attribution, conformity, obedience, culture, groups, prejudice and discrimination from a psychological perspective.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite PSYCH 100

courses.description: The focus of this course in general is on the psychological study of gender in historical and contemporary perspective. The historical roots of gender studies in women's studies, as a correction to a traditional focus on male and masculine perspectives, will be covered.

courses.description: Introductory analysis of the employment relationship and the interrelated interests of management, workers, unions, and the public.

courses.description: Development of Anglo-American law regulating collective bargaining, with emphasis on American labor-management relations under Wagner, Taft-Hartley, and other acts.

courses.description: Explores ethics from both a normative and behavioral perspective; four interrelated and mutually reinforcing subject areas will be explored in the course at the individual, organizational and transnational levels business ethics, ethics in unionized firms, corporate social responsibility, and sustainability.

courses.title: Leadership and Motivation
courses.description: Applies organizational behavior theories, concepts, and skills to leading and motivating individuals and groups.

courses.title: Management and Organization
courses.description: Designing organizations to effectively manage new technologies, structures, and people in changing global contexts.

courses.description: Leaders, in whatever context, make difficult decisions, distribute scarce resources, direct and influence the conduct of others, and represent the goals of the enterprise they lead. Thus they ought to exemplify prudence, fairness, integrity, honesty, trustworthiness, sincerity, and morally upright behavior. This course investigates these concepts and the moral dilemmas that arise in developing or applying them.

courses.description: Supply chain management concepts, principles, and methodologies.

courses.description: A survey of the major aspects of international business environment and operations with an emphasis on the cultural dimension.

courses.title: Information, People and Technology
courses.description: The use, analysis, and design of information systems and technologies to organize, coordinate, and inform human enterprises.

courses.title: Race, Gender, and Employment
courses.description: Employment relations and legislative and policy responses to labor force issues of racial and gender inequality.

courses.title: Employment Relationship: Law and Policy
courses.description: Examination of basic legal principles underlying the employment relationship, and their social, political, and economic bases.

courses.title: History of Work in America
courses.description: A study of selected problems in the history of work in the United States, especially since 1877.

courses.description: The role of human biology and evolution in culture, society, and behavior.

courses.title: Humans as Primates

courses.description: This course is designed to increase student awareness of personal, interpersonal, and societal aspects of disability, including how disability can be defined and understood differently in varied individual, institutional, and cultural contexts.

courses.description: A study of the fundamental concepts of biology, including the evolution of the major groups of organisms. This is the first biology course taken by students who intend to major in biology. It provides a foundation in the basic concepts that govern life, including the evolutionary processes that have led to the biodiversity seen today.

courses.description: Normal structure and function of the animal body, with special emphasis on human body systems.

courses.title: Introduction to the Biology of Aging
courses.description: Examination of human aging from a biological perspective. Population demographics, physiological and pathological changes, and healthy lifestyles are discussed. Students who have passed BIOL 409 may not schedule this course.

courses.title: Human Anatomy and Physiology I - Lecture
courses.description: Human Anatomy and Physiology I - Lecture

courses.title: Biology of Sex
courses.description: Basic structure and function of the human reproductive system. Physiology of gametogenesis, fertilization, contraception, gestation, parturition, lactation, and sexual behavior.

courses.title: Chemical Principles I
courses.description: Basic concepts and quantitative relations.

courses.title: Experimental Chemistry I
courses.description: Introduction to quantitative experimentation in chemistry.

courses.title: Leisure and Human Behavior
courses.description: Leisure from historical and contemporary perspectives, including forces shaping leisure behavior, and relationships among leisure, the environment, and social institutions.

courses.description: Provides students with strong foundational knowledge about sustainability and how it relates to their career in recreation, park, and tourism management.

courses.description: Supervision in recreation services, including theories, strategies, group dynamics, applied leadership, and decision-making skills.

courses.description: Examines the governmental systems that influence the delivery of recreational services. The formal structure of government is considered along with the day-to-day political processes that determine public policy.

courses.description: Theoretical/practical application of marketing/advertising strategies in the development/delivery of recreation services.

courses.description: Systematic, structured problem-solving process for decision-making in recreation and parks. Research techniques/evaluation procedures; quantitative, qualitative methodologies; deductive, inductive reasoning.

courses.title: Introduction to Community Recreation
courses.description: Introduces students to the role of community and nonprofit recreation agencies in generating benefits for individuals and communities. Topics include: the history of community and nonprofit recreation; environmental, economic, health, social, and human development benefits of recreation; access and equity issues in recreation and community sport; engaging communities in decision-making; the experience industry; and designing community recreation programs and spaces for meaningful experiences.

courses.title: Nonprofit Recreation Agency Operations
courses.description: Introduces students to the operational practices and missions of nonprofit recreation and tourism organizations. In particular, this course will allow students to investigate voluntary and semi-private sectors through membership strategies, fundraising and development roles, and volunteer management.

courses.title: Orientation to Internship
courses.description: Plan and prepare for an internship in recreation services. Analyze career opportunities, internship process, and associated requirements.

courses.title: Internship in Recreation Services
courses.description: Meet educational objectives through participation in an organized practical experience. In most instances, students are engaged in an off-campus learning experience that aligns with their specific field of study.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite RPTM 394andRPTM 456and seventh-semester standing and C average. Recommended preparation 300 hours practical experience and current and valid certification in advanced first aid and CPR or Wilderness First Aid/First Responder.

courses.title: Communication and Information Technology I
courses.description: Introduction to communication technology and information management; intended for students in the liberal arts.

courses.title: Introduction to Arena Management
courses.description: Introduction to arena and facilities management, including operations, budgeting, marketing, and staffing.

courses.title: Recreation Facilities Planning and Management
courses.description: Planning and management of selected facilities with emphasis upon maintenance, activity, and support provisions.

rules.name: Prescribed Courses for the Major (30 credits)

courses.title: Overview of Information Security
courses.description: Provides an understanding of the overview of information security, including security architecture, access control, and internet secure applications.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite SRA 111andIST 110andCMPSC 101

courses.title: Information, People and Technology
courses.description: The use, analysis, and design of information systems and technologies to organize, coordinate, and inform human enterprises.

courses.title: Organization of Data
courses.description: Introduction to the concept of databases, including the storage, manipulation, evaluation, and display of data, and related issues.

courses.title: Legal and Regulatory Environment of Information Science and Technology
courses.description: Legal environment of information technology, constitutional/political issues, intellectual property, management, e-commerce, privacy, access, computer contracting, cyberspace regulation.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite IST 301orSRA 231

courses.title: Internship
courses.description: Supervised off-campus, nongroup instruction including field experiences, practica, or internships. Written and oral critique of activity required.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite prior approval of proposed assignment by instructor Note Internships provide valuable experience for students; however, we recognize that situations vary and some students, due to work or other commitments, are unable to adjust their schedules. You are encouraged to contact your adviser to make arrangements for suitable activities in lieu of an internship.

courses.title: Introduction to Security and Risk Analysis
courses.description: This introductory course spans areas of security, risk, and analysis covering contexts in government agencies and business organizations.

courses.title: Threat of Terrorism and Crime
courses.description: Provides overview of nature, scope, and seriousness of threats to security as a result of terrorism and crime.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite SRA 111andCMPSC 101orIST 140andCMPSC 121 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Decision Theory and Analysis
courses.description: Provides an overview of decision theoretical and analytical concepts and tools in the security risk analysis field.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite SRA 211,STAT 200

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive Statistics, frequency distributions, probability and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite Placement intoMATH 21or higher.

courses.title: Effective Writing: Technical Writing
courses.description: Writing for students in scientific and technical disciplines.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite ENGL 15,ESL 15,ENGL 30, and 4th Semester standing ORENGL 137H,ENGL 138T, and 4th Semester standing

courses.title: Effective Writing: Business Writing
courses.description: Writing reports and other common forms of business communication.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite (ENGL 15 orESL 15 orENGL 30) and 4th-semester standing OR (ENGL 137H andENGL 138T) and 4th-semester standing

courses.title: Introductory Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to general psychology; principles of human behavior and their applications.
courses.prerequisites_text: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Social Problems
courses.description: Current social problems such as economic, racial, and gender inequalities; social deviance and crime; population, environmental, energy, and health problems.
courses.prerequisites_text: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Economic Principles of Agribusiness Decision Making
courses.description: This course introduces students to microeconomic principles in the context of food and agriculture.

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.

courses.title: Introductory Macroeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: National income measurement; aggregate economic models; money and income; policy problems.

courses.title: College Algebra With Analytic Geometry and Applications II
courses.description: Relations, functions, graphs; polynomial, rational functions, graphs; word problems; nonlinear inequalities; inverse functions; exponential, logarithmic functions; conic sections; simultaneous equations.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MATH 021or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination.

courses.title: Plane Trigonometry and Applications of Trigonometry
courses.description: Trigonometric functions; solutions of triangles; trigonometric equations; identities.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MATH 21 or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Techniques of Calculus I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change, and the underlying mathematical behaviors that model real-life economics and financial applications. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques, and how to use a calculus framework to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MATH 22orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination

courses.title: Calculus With Analytic Geometry I
courses.description: Introduces and develops the mathematical skills required for analyzing change and creating mathematical models that replicate real-life phenomena. Develops student knowledge of calculus techniques and how to use the calculus environment to develop critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MATH 22andMATH 26orMATH 26and satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination orMATH 40orMATH 41or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination.

courses.title: Geography of International Affairs
courses.description: Contemporary international affairs in their geographical setting; geographic elements in the development of national power, political groupings, and international disputes.

courses.title: American Politics: Principles, Processes and Powers
courses.description: This course examines the American democracy by looking at the dynamic interaction between the founding ideals of the United States government, the institutions established by the Constitution, and the ongoing contest for power within and through those institutions.

courses.title: International Relations
courses.description: Characteristics of modern nation-states and forces governing their international relations; nationalism; imperialism; diplomacy; current problems of war and peace.

courses.title: Statistics for Security and Risk Analysis
courses.description: This course emphasizes how to summarize data using descriptive statistics, how to make data-driven decisions using inferential statistics, and how to critically evaluate data presented in the media, all within the context of security, risk, and analysis. This is both a theory and application course. Students will learn about statistical theories, such as regression, and chi-square analyses, and apply their knowledge of these theories by analyzing and interpreting data using a statistical software package.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite STAT 200 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Intermediate Applied Statistics
courses.description: Review of hypothesis testing, goodness-of-fit tests, regression, correlation analysis, completely randomized designs, randomized complete block designs, latin squares.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite STAT 200orSTAT 240orSTAT 250orSTAT 401 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming
courses.description: Fundamentals of computational thinking, including reasoning about problems at multiple levels of abstraction, and analyzing code for its behavior, efficiency, and correctness.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MATH 21or satisfactory performance on the mathematics placement examination C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Programming Techniques
courses.description: Introduction to programming techniques design and implementation of algorithms. Structured programming. Problem-solving techniques. Introduction to a high-level language, including arrays, procedures, and recursion
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MATH 110or prerequisite or concurrentMATH 140 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

courses.title: Introduction to Application Development
courses.description: A first course in concepts and skills for application development.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite C or better inMATH 21or placement above the level ofMATH 21in the mathematics placement test. Recommend preparation MATH 22 C or better A student enrolled in this course must receive a grade of C or better.

rules.name: Prescribed Courses for the Intelligence Analysis and Modeling Option (21 credits)

courses.title: Legal and Regulatory Environment of Privacy and Security
courses.description: Exploration of legal, regulatory, public policy, and ethical issues related to security and privacy for information technology professionals in public institutions, private enterprise, and IT services.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite IST 432

courses.title: Visual Analytics
courses.description: This course introduces the fundamental principles, methods, and tools of visual analytics that enable security and risk analysts to synthesize information and derive insight from massive, dynamic, ambiguous, and often conflicting data.

courses.title: Risk Analysis in a Security Context
courses.description: This course provides students with the background, experience, and perspective required to document risk and identify policies and procedures that effectively deal with hazards and threats to which the organization is vulnerable, jeopardizing its mission.

courses.title: The Intelligence Environment
courses.description: The course examines the users and processes of Intelligence Community, participants of Competitive Intelligence, and comparative intelligence communities.

courses.title: Deception and Counterdeception
courses.description: Deception tactics, technologies and procedures, and approaches to counterdeception analysis.

courses.title: Security and Risk Analysis Capstone Course
courses.description: The Security and Risk Analysis Capstone course is designed to provide IST students enrolled in the SRA major to experience a semester-long security and risk problem-solving experience, providing realistic security dilemmas requiring a solution process that is well suited for teamwork and collaboration.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite SRA 221andSRA 311andENGL 202CorENGL 202D

courses.title: Spatial Analysis of Risks
courses.description: Helps students develop a spatial perspective on risk analysis and empowers them with GIS spatial data representation, visualization, and analysis methods that are fundamental to the spatial analysis of risk.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite SRA 111

courses.title: Network Security
courses.description: Fundamental issues and concepts of network security, network security technologies and protocols, and emerging technologies in network security.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221

courses.title: Computer and Cyber Forensics
courses.description: Fundamental issues and concepts of computer forensics; aspects of computer and cyber crime; methods to uncover, protect, exploit, and document digital evidence; tools, techniques, and procedures to perform computer and cyber crime investigation.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221

courses.title: Information Security Management
courses.description: Contemporary security issues; security management processes, architecture, and models; risk analysis and management; security planning, analysis, and safeguards; security policies development and administration; contingency planning, incidence handling, and response; and security standards and certification processes.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite C or better inIST 220andSRA 221

courses.title: Networking and Telecommunications
courses.description: Introduction to digital network topologies, transmission media, signal modulation, digital packet switching and routing, systems integration, communications management, and security.

courses.title: Risk Analysis in a Security Context
courses.description: Assessment and mitigation of security vulnerabilities for people, organizations, industry sectors, and the nation.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite SRA 231

courses.title: Database Management Systems

rules.name: Supporting Courses and Related Areas (select 9 credits)

courses.title: Applied Machine Learning in Data Science
courses.description: This course will start with an overview of supervised and unsupervised learning, and introduce the associated libraries. It covers basic machine learning concepts, tasks, and workflow using an example classification problem based on K-nearest neighbors, Naïve Bayes, Support Vector Machine (SVM), K-means, and implementation using Python libraries.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite STAT 318andMATH 220 and(CMPSC 122 orCMPSC 132)

courses.title: Engineering Quality and Security in Software
courses.description: This course introduces software quality, the associated quality factors, software errors and the software quality assurance system.

courses.title: Basic News Writing Skills
courses.description: Grammar, punctuation, spelling, and word usage skills required of journalists.

courses.title: Writing for Media
courses.description: This course is an introduction to writing for various kinds of mass communication media. Students will practice writing public relations news releases; public information announcements; print, television and radio advertisements; and news stories and editorials. Students will be given weekly writing assignments, some of which will be re-writes of earlier submissions. In-class exercises will include various writing exercises designed to get students more comfortable with writing for media.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite ENGL 15andENGL 202

courses.title: Principles of Strategic Communications
courses.description: Provides an overview of the various media and communications methods that comprise modern integrated marketing campaigns.

courses.title: Strategic Communications Law
courses.description: Analysis of laws and regulations affecting online advertising and strategic communications.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite COMM 428Aand permission of the program

courses.title: Strategic Communications in a Global Environment
courses.description: Framework for applying public relations and advertising tools across media platforms and across cultures.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite COMM 428A,COMM 428Dand permission of the program

courses.title: Research & Analytics
courses.description: Online research methods for strategic communication, including web analytics, online surveys, online interviews, and content analysis.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite COMM 428A,STAT 200and permission of the program

courses.title: Social Media Strategies
courses.description: Social media — including social networks, visual content, podcasts, blogs and other collaborative content creation platforms — are changing the field of public relations. To effectively deploy social media to reach brand objectives, public relations professionals need to understand the critical roles of strategy as well as content creation. This course narrows the focus from the broad field of social media to cover the specific tools and best practices needed to conquer current and future use of social media in public relations

courses.title: Introductory Microeconomic Analysis and Policy
courses.description: Methods of economic analysis and their use; price determination; theory of the firm; distribution.

courses.title: Introductory Psychology
courses.description: Introduction to general psychology; principles of human behavior and their applications.

courses.title: Elementary Statistics
courses.description: Descriptive statistics, frequency distributions, probability, binomial and normal distributions, statistical inference, linear regression, and correlation.

courses.description: Nature and theories of law; the Supreme Court and press freedom; legal problems of the mass media.

courses.title: News Media Ethics
courses.description: Ethical problems in the practice of journalism; principal public criticisms of news media; case study approach.

courses.title: Sports, Media, and Society
courses.description: Sport and media relationship in American culture.

courses.description: Development of quantitative problem-solving skills applied to specific examples of agribusiness management problems, using Excel spreadsheets.

courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite CHEM 101orCHEM 110,CHEM 110HorCHEM 106

courses.description: Introduction to entomology and management of insect pests of cold- and warm-season turfgrass.

courses.description: Quadratic equations; equation in quadratic form; word problems; graphing; algebraic fractions; negative and rational exponents; radicals.

courses.description: Introduction to biology of turfgrass pathogens and management of cool- and warm-season turfgrass.

courses.description: A study of soil properties and processes and relationships to land use, plant growth, environmental quality, and society.

courses.description: Covers chemical toxicity, formulations, environmental fate, labels, MSDS, calibration, IPM, safety, handling, storage, and Pennsylvania certification and regulations.
