courses.description: Characterization of the primary plant species used for sports, lawn and utility turf; includes turfgrass morphology, environmental adaptation, and cultural requirements.

courses.description: Introduction to the development of integrated weed management strategies utilizing a variety of cultural and chemical methods.

courses.description: A study of irrigation topics with a strong concentration on turfgrass irrigation applications and a focus on surface and subsurface drainage.

courses.description: A study of turfgrass maintenance practices and how their interrelationships can be utilized to develop management systems.

courses.description: Supervised off-campus, nongroup instruction including field experiences, practica, or internships. Written and oral critique of activity required.

courses.description: A study of the fundamental concepts of biology, including the evolution of the major groups of organisms. This is the first biology course taken by students who intend to major in biology. It provides a foundation in the basic concepts that govern life, including the evolutionary processes that have led to the biodiversity seen today.

courses.title: Introduction to Plant Biology
courses.description: Cellular structure, organization, and metabolism; plant anatomy and physiological processes; plant reproduction and development; genetics and evolution; relationships and features of plant groups. Students who have passed BIOL 240W may not schedule this course.

courses.description: Introduction to horticulture with an emphasis on plant domestication, morphology, classification, world food crops, commodities, gardens, propagation, and agrochemicals. The course content deals with the fundamental concepts and specialty areas, which contribute not only to the science and technology involved in horticulture but also to the art.

courses.title: Diversity and Health
courses.description: Examines the relationship diverse personal and sociocultural factors (e.g., socioeconomic class, race-ethnicity, gender, age, and sexual orientation) have with health.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite PSYCH 100orSOC 1

courses.title: Gender and Biobehavioral Health
courses.description: Interdisciplinary study of gender, examining the interaction of biological, behavioral, and sociocultural factors on health differentials throughout the lifespan.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite BBH 101

courses.title: Intercultural Communication
courses.description: Focus on topics such as language, identity, prejudice, and intergroup relations on a domestic/ international level.

courses.title: Communication Ethics
courses.description: Ethical issues in public and private communication; role of communication in expressing and realizing individual and social values.

courses.title: Gender Roles in Communications
courses.description: Explores the literature on gender research in the discipline of human communication.

courses.title: Studies in Public Address
courses.description: History and criticism of public discourse; intensive analysis of selected public addresses and social movements.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite 6 credits of CAS

courses.title: World Literatures
courses.description: The development of literature around the world - from epic, legend, lyric, etc. in the oral tradition to modern written forms.

courses.title: International Cultures: Film and Literature
courses.description: Comparison of narrative techniques employed by literature and film in portraying different cultures, topics may vary each semester.

courses.title: Gender, Diversity and the Media
courses.description: Examines diversity, equity, and inclusion issues in media content, media business, and media practice.

courses.title: Presumed Innocent? Social Science of Wrongful Conviction
courses.description: The criminal justice system is a human creation and some errors are expected. Sometimes guilty parties go free and sometimes innocent people are convicted. In this course, we will employ the perspective of the social scientist to understand why and how wrongful convictions occur.

courses.title: Presumed Innocent? Social Science of Wrongful Conviction
courses.description: The criminal justice system is a human creation and some errors are expected. Sometimes guilty parties go free and sometimes innocent people are convicted. In this course, we will employ the perspective of the social scientist to understand why and how wrongful convictions occur.

courses.title: Deaf Culture
courses.description: Explores the economic, social, psychological, and political aspects of the deaf culture and its interaction with the majority hearing culture.

courses.title: Introduction to LGBTQ Studies
courses.description: Learn about the dominant themes in Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Queer Studies, with an emphasis on both literary and cultural studies. This course explores the history of modern, Western ideas about sexual identity as manifested in literature, theatre, film, and other narrative forms of popular culture.

courses.title: Introduction to LGBTQ Studies
courses.description: Learn about the dominant themes in Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual, Transgender, and Queer Studies, with an emphasis on both literary and cultural studies. This course explores the history of modern, Western ideas about sexual identity as manifested in literature, theatre, film, and other narrative forms of popular culture.

courses.title: Adult Development and Aging
courses.description: Physiological, psychological, and social development and intervention from young adulthood through old age.

courses.title: Sexual Identity over the Life Span
courses.description: Concepts of affectional and sexual orientation over life span, with emphasis on lesbian and gay male personal, family, and community adaptation.

courses.title: Reading Our Lives: Understanding Diversity and Human Development through Memoirs
courses.description: Students will explore the way people and their environments interact to influence human development through the integration of memoirs and other personal narratives, humanist themes and methods of inquiry, and social science theory and research.

courses.title: Recent American History
courses.description: Contemporary economic, social, and political aspects of the United States and its role as a world power since 1945.

courses.title: History of Work in America
courses.description: A study of selected problems in the history of work in the United States, especially since 1877.

courses.title: History of Work in America
courses.description: A study of selected problems in the history of work in the United States, especially since 1877.

courses.title: History of Imperialism and Nationalism in Africa
courses.description: A selective overview of the history of imperialism and nationalism in Africa.

courses.title: Leadership in a Global Context
courses.description: This course explores the science and practice of leadership around the globe through pertinent scholarly literature and related instructional resources.

courses.title: Women and Leadership
courses.description: Overviews scholarship relating to women in positions of leadership in groups and organizations, as well as obstacles to their success.

courses.title: Rights in America
courses.description: This course explores the historical and contemporary struggles of particular groups within American society to expand their rights.

courses.title: Introduction to Disability Culture
courses.description: This course is designed to increase student awareness of personal, interpersonal, and societal aspects of disability, including how disability can be defined and understood differently in varied individual, institutional, and cultural contexts.

courses.title: Introduction to World Religions
courses.description: The course introduces students to the academic study of religion as well as to some of the major religious traditions of the world.

courses.title: Leisure and Human Behavior
courses.description: Leisure from historical and contemporary perspectives, including forces shaping leisure behavior, and relationships among leisure, the environment, and social institutions.

courses.title: Race, Ethnicity and Culture
courses.description: Focuses on historical patterns and current status of racial, ethnic and cultural groups and issues locally, nationally, and internationally.

courses.title: Gender, Occupations, and Professions
courses.description: The role of gender in shaping contemporary North American patterns of employment, occupational roles, and statuses.

courses.title: Introduction to Autism Spectrum Disorders
courses.description: This course will include an overview of characteristics and learning traits, classification systems, assessment strategies/issues, approaches, and interventions related to individuals with autism spectrum disorders (ASDs). Special emphasis will be given to selecting evidence-based practices and enhancing collaboration among individuals with ASD, their families, and supporting professionals.

courses.title: Introduction to Women's and Gender Studies
courses.description: Review scholarly theories and research pertaining to women’s experiences and women’s status in contemporary American society.

courses.title: Representing Women and Gender in Literature, Art and Popular Cultures
courses.description: Explore scholarly theories and research pertaining to women and gender while experiencing examples of contemporary women’s creative practice through the visual arts, media, and popular culture.

courses.title: Sex, Gender, and the Body
courses.description: This introductory course considers core topics in the field of feminist sexuality studies to both unsettle popular mainstream discourses on sexuality and to aid students in developing a more comprehensive, inclusive, and ethical lens through which to view intersections of gender, sexuality, and the body.

courses.title: Earth in the Future:  Predicting Climate Change and Its Impacts Over the   Next Century
courses.description: Climate predictions for the coming century are utilized to examine potential impacts on regions, sectors of society, and natural ecosystems.

courses.title: Climate, Energy and Our Future
courses.description: This course presents the past, present, and possible future response of Earth's climate to human energy use.

courses.title: Coastal Processes, Hazards and Society
courses.description: Outcomes include the processes responsible for formation, diversity, and evolution of coastal landscapes; socioeconomic and policy responses to changes in coastal regions.

courses.title: The Fundamentals of Shale Energy Development
courses.description: Energy is a critical component of modern society, yet we face significant challenges associated with balancing energy demands, energy security, environmental sustainability, and stable economics with sound regulations and policy. Unconventional energy development from shale formations has been a game changer for the fossil fuel industry over the past decade and is projected to continue to grow over the next several decades.

courses.title: Water: Science and Society
courses.description: Students will investigate water behavior and occurrence, and its relevance to life, human activities, politics, and society.

courses.title: Food and the Future Environment
courses.description: Introduces students to the multiple connections of people and the environment through the dynamics of food and the places where it is produced, processed, and consumed.

id: Enterprise Resource Planning Certificate with SAP

courses.title: Introduction to ERP and Business Processes
courses.description: A problem-based, interdisciplinary course on Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) concepts to help you understand the integrated software modules used to run virtually all business processes in an organization. This course explains and demonstrates in detail how business processes such as sales logistics, production/material management, procurement, and human resources are supported in an ERP software package.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite MIS 204or first-level programming course or with permission from the program

courses.title: Operations Planning and Control
courses.description: Gain detailed information on planning and control systems for business operations, including aggregate production planning procedures, disaggregation methods in hierarchical production planning, sales and operations planning, master production scheduling, material requirements planning, production activity control, lot-sizing, and capacity planning.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite SCM 301 Note This is a unique version of this course, supplemented with SAP–specific course work and may only be taken through World Campus to count toward the certificate; transfer credit will not be considered, including from another Penn State campus.

courses.title: Purchasing and Materials Management
courses.description: Focuses on materials management and purchasing policies, procedures, and goals, including the role of purchasing in production planning and inventory management.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite SCM 301orSCM 310 Note This is a unique version of this course, supplemented with SAP–specific course work and may only be taken through World Campus to count toward the certificate; transfer credit will not be considered, including from another Penn State campus.

courses.title: Federal Taxation I
courses.description: Study of income determination concepts for individuals and corporations, impact of taxation on decisions, elementary research techniques, and ethical standards.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite ACCTG 211orFIN 301 FIN 301 Prerequisites (ENGL 15orENGL 30orESL 15orENGL 137HorCAS 137H) andACCTG 211and (ECON 102or ECON 104) and (SCM 200orSTAT 200)

courses.title: Personal Financial Planning
courses.description: Developing financial plans including cash budgets, credit purchases, investments, and insurance.
courses.prerequisites_text: Note Third-semester standing or permission of instructor.

courses.title: Investment and Portfolio Analysis
courses.description: Investment and risk, types of security investments, sources of investment information, the broker, the stock market, portfolio management.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite FIN 301 FIN 301 Prerequisites (ENGL 15orENGL 30orESL 15orENGL 137HorCAS 137H) andACCTG 211and (ECON 102or ECON 104) and (SCM 200orSTAT 200)

courses.title: Estate Planning
courses.description: Liquidity planning, titling and transfer of property, trusts, federal unified tax system, gifting, incapacity planning, legal documents.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite FIN 330andACCTG 310orACCTG 405

courses.title: Retirement Planning
courses.description: Retirement planning: qualified and non-qualified plans, characteristics, provisions, regulations administration, application approach with case studies.

courses.title: Financial Planning Capstone
courses.description: Critical thinking and decision-making about personal financial planning topics in the context of the financial planning process.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite completion of first 15 credits of the certificate curriculum

courses.title: Information, People and Technology
courses.description: The use, analysis, and design of information systems and technologies to organize, coordinate, and inform human enterprises.
courses.prerequisites_text: Note The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Organization of Data
courses.description: Introduction to the concept of databases, including the storage, manipulation, evaluation, and display of data, and related issues.

courses.title: Networking and Telecommunications
courses.description: Introduction to digital network topologies, transmission media, signal modulation, digital packet switching and routing, systems integration, communications management, and security.

courses.title: Introduction to Web Design and Development
courses.description: Introduction to how the World Wide Web utilizes emerging technologies. Students acquire a conceptual understanding of constructing websites.

courses.title: Exploring Work and Employment
courses.description: Introductory analysis of the employment relationship and the interrelated interests of management, workers, unions, and the public.
courses.prerequisites_text: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Employment Relationship: Law and Policy
courses.description: Examination of basic legal principles underlying the employment relationship, and their social, political, and economic bases.
courses.prerequisites_text: GS The credits earned in this course may be applied toward the Social and Behavioral Sciences (GS) requirement.

courses.title: Labor and Employment Relations Fundamentals
courses.description: The course surveys the main elements of modern labor and employment relations systems in the U.S. and beyond.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite LHR 100

courses.title: Human Resources Fundamentals
courses.description: This course will help students understand the manner in which employees and employers interact at work.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite LHR 100

courses.title: Comparative Employment Relations Systems
courses.description: Analysis of structure and elements of employment relations systems in developed and developing areas.

courses.title: International Human Resource Studies
courses.description: Course exploring human resource management from an international perspective.

courses.title: Violence and the Impact on Society
courses.description: Interdisciplinary discussion of violence and its perpetrators, victims, and impact on society as well as possible solutions for violence reduction.

courses.title: Introduction to Forensic Nursing
courses.description: Provides an introduction to the forensic health sciences, forensic nursing, and the nursing role in the scientific investigation of violence.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite NURS 250andNURS 225andNURS 230

courses.title: Forensic Evidence Collection and Preservation
courses.description: Examines a forensic nurse's role recognizing injuries/patterns of injury. Evidence collection procedures are examined from collection to courtroom presentation.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite or concurrent NURS 245andNURS 409

courses.title: Seminar in Forensic Nursing
courses.description: A seminar to discuss the current topics, trends, and research related to forensic nursing, including evidence-based research, public policy issues, media-related events, regulatory considerations, professional responsibilities, and career planning.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite or concurrent NURS 410

courses.title: Introduction to Nursing Informatics
courses.description: An introduction to nursing informatics focusing on technology applications to the nursing profession.

courses.title: Ethical Challenges in Health Care Informatics
courses.description: A case-based collaboratory designed for the exploration and analysis of the ethical dilemmas facing health care informatics practitioners.

courses.title: Advanced Concepts in Clinical Nursing Informatics
courses.description: An exploration of clinical informatics tools to support informatics practice.

courses.title: Communication and Information Technology I
courses.description: Introduction to communication technology and information management; intended for students in the liberal arts.

courses.title: Organizational Communication
courses.description: Examines the function and structure of communication in both formal and informal situations.

courses.title: Conflict Resolution and Negotiation
courses.description: Theories and strategies important for conceptualizing, developing, and managing conflict negotiation, mediation, and third-party intervention.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite 6 credits of CAS

courses.title: Organizational Communication Theory and Research
courses.description: Explores the nature and functions of communication in organizations, with emphasis on concepts, tools, and skills for effective management of communication.
courses.prerequisites_text: Prerequisite CAS 202orCAS 252

courses.title: Studies in Public Address
courses.description: History and criticism of public discourse; intensive analysis of selected public addresses and social movements.

courses.description: Preparing and editing reports and presentations common to business, industry, and government.

courses.description: Leadership Development in Snowsports develops students' understanding and skills in becoming a Snowsports industry professional.

courses.description: Provides overview of nature, scope, and seriousness of threats to security as a result of terrorism and crime.

courses.description: Fundamentals of computational thinking, including reasoning about problems at multiple levels of abstraction, and analyzing code for its behavior, efficiency, and correctness.
